banner.text: ü§ì Make sure your Motion sensor is plugged in for this challenge.
Let's use the power of code to make a pig fly üê∑!

First, let's set the scene by drawing the sky.
Open the draw tray.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Nice! Now choose your favorite sky blue, like #33ccff.

You'll need to use a sticker for the pig.
Open the parts drawer on the right of the screen.

tooltips.text: Click on Sticker to add it to your app

banner.text:
Now, let's change it into a pig üê∑.
Open the Sticker tray.
This block changes the sticker... drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Now change Bee to Pig. Oink oink!

Great... now let's change the pig's posiiton.
Open the Sticker tray.
This block moves the sticker... drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Now open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Let's move the pig to the right side of the canvas.
Change 0 to 400.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Now, let's move the pig to the bottom right corner of the canvas.
Change 0 to 250.

Nice! We also need a loop to make it move.
Open the Control tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Change seconds to frames.

Now let's make that pig fly!
Open the Sticker tray.
This block moves a sticker forward... drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Let's move it to the left.
Change 0 to -2.

Wow... look at it go!
Now let's steer it with the Motion Sensor.
Open the Sticker tray again.
This block rotates a sticker... drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Awesome. Now let's use a lerp block to tweak the Sensor value.
Open the Math tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Change 200 to 10 to make the pig spin slower.

Now let's add the Motion Sensor.
Open the Motion tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Move your hand over the sensor... can you steer the pig?
Great! Next we'll turn the pig into a sky writer üêñüí≠.
Open the Draw tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Let's use the position of the pig to draw a smoke trail.
Open the Sticker tray again.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Open the Sticker tray for the y position (the vertical, or bottom to top position).
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Hmmm... you need to move the pen to the middle of the pig.
Open the Draw tray.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.

The pig is about 100 pixels wide...
Change 5 to 50 to find the middle.
Change 5 to 50.

Now, let's choose a color for the smoke.
Open the Draw tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Choose a color for the smoke, like #ffffff or #ff8ad8.

Now... let's draw the smoke!
Open the Draw tray again.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Steer the pig around again... you made smoke!
Hmmm... it's not very smokey. Let's fix that.

You'll use move blocks and random blocks to make a smokey effect.
Open the Draw tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Now let's use some random blocks.
Open the Math tray.

This block chooses a random number every time the code runs.
Drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Change 0 to -5.
Change 10 to 5.
Open the Math tray and grab another random block.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Change 0 to -5.
Change 10 to 5.

One last thing... let's draw more smoke!
Open the Draw tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Steer the pig around again... can you see how random blocks makes it look like smoke plumes?
Well done! Now, can you try and make the pig fly faster?
